thread.title: Obama to Castro: Reform in Cuba will boost benefits from closer ties
thread.title_full: Obama to Castro: Reform in Cuba will boost benefits from closer ties | Fox News Latino

author: EFE
title: Obama to Castro: Reform in Cuba will boost benefits from closer ties
text:
EFE (re-ledes with White House take on meeting)
President Barack Obama on Tuesday told Cuban leader Raul Castro that "continued reforms" in his country would "increase the impact" of changes adopted by his government to ease the embargo on the island, according to the White House.
During the meeting of the two presidents at United Nations headquarters, Obama also repeated to Castro the "support" of the United States for human rights in Cuba, the White House said in a communique.
In that sense, White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters in a plane on the way back to Washington that Obama "reaffirmed our commitment to seeing the Cuban government doing a better job of not only respecting but also actively protecting the human rights of the Cuban people," and urged Castro to move Cuba "in a positive direction."
The White House said in the communique that the meeting was focused on discussing the "recent advances in relations between the United States and Cuba, as well as additional steps each government can take to deepen bilateral cooperation."
Obama emphasized to Castro the recent "regulatory changes that will allow more Americans to travel to and do business with Cuba, while helping to improve the lives of the Cuban people."
Last week new regulations were adopted by the U.S. government that will allow its citizens greater opportunities to travel, do business, send remittances and provide telecommunications services to Cuba, though tourism is still banned.
According to the White House, Obama also highlighted the "progress" signified by the renewal of diplomatic relations with the reopening last July of the embassies in Washington and Havana.
Obama and Castro also discussed the recent "successful visit" of Pope Francis to Cuba and the U.S.
Cuba's foreign minister said that Castro asked Obama to use his executive power to ease the economic embargo if he wants to continue making progress in normalizing relations.
Bruno Rodriguez spoke to reporters after the two presidents met at U.N. headquarters.
"The pace of the process toward normalization of relations between Cuba and the United States will depend on the lifting of the blockade," Rodriguez said, adding that the executive decisions taken by Obama up to now "have a very limited value, a very limited scope."
The U.S. president has executive powers that "are very broad, and they deal with tens of areas," and they permit him to substantially modify many elements of the embargo, the foreign minister said.
According to Rodriguez, Obama's actions in that regard have not yet made any significant change in the embargo against Cuba.
Since the announcement last December of a process to normalize bilateral relations, Obama has asked without success that the Republican-controlled Congress eliminate the economic embargo imposed on Cuba in 1962.
Castro, in his speech this Monday before the U.N. General Assembly, made it clear that the normalizing of ties will only be achieved, among other things, "with the end of the economic, commercial and financial blockade" against Cuba.
In Tuesday's meeting, the second that the two presidents have held since the normalization process got underway, the Cuban leader repeated Havana's "willingness to work to build a new kind of relations between the two countries."
The meeting, the foreign minister said, was held in a "respectful and constructive climate" and served to exchange impressions about Pope Francis's visit to the two countries, cooperation in mutually beneficial areas, and dealing with problems that are still pending.
Rodriguez recalled that the two countries now have an ongoing dialogue on numerous matters such as the environment, the war on drugs, search and rescue operations for people lost at sea, terrorism and health.
Cuba also said it is ready to discuss the process of economic reparations to resolve the demands that the two countries are making against each other.
The foreign minister said, however, that Washington and Havana continue having major differences.
Among other things, Rodriguez recalled that his government considers the return of the territory occupied by the U.S. Navy base at Guantanamo to be a high-priority element in the normalization process.
But at the same time, he said there remains "an opportunity of making significant advances in the normalization of bilateral relations during Obama's administration."
Rodriguez recalled that Castro considers Obama an "honest man" and that he admires "his humble origins" and said that the meetings between the two have always been "cordial." EFE
